title: If I asked you to teach me something really cool or interesting in five minutes, what would you teach? - Quora

response.answer_text: First thought: Okay, so far, me personally, I don’t like the other answers here. So I’ll answer something different. . Second thought: Besides, teach positivity and motivation in just five minutes? Also, how long does it take to read that? Nevermind. If I’m gonna teach you something quick, it must be something you relate to, understand, or makes sense to you. That way, it will be easy for you to learn. . Third, thought: I’ve given answers like that already. But what… hmm… oh, I know! How to talk to girls. So it goes like this. Instead of asking what girls are looking for, ask what girls are not looking for: Anxiety. Anxiety is the true women repellant. But you can go to the restroom and release it before talking to women. Chewing gum might help too. Make sure it’s icy mint not mouthwash flavor. Two birds with one stone. Don’t rely too much on either the restroom or chewing gum, cuz at any moment you could find yourself without both. Either way, remember all the time, no anxiety. And if something isn’t working, examine yourself to see if you’re being anxious.Too nice or too rude. If you’re too nice, she will see you as a doormat (even if you’re not), and you’ll get friendzoned. Well, the other extreme is also bad. Don’t be too rude. Cuz nobody wants to be with someone who’s just gonna make them feel bad all the time and never do anything nice for them or tell them anything nice. So be nice, but not too nice.A sense of humor. And this is more than just making jokes or knowing jokes. It’s also clever comnents with comedic timing. This is a bit of a weak example, but my grandpa was once talking with someone who said “I cannot drink coffee at night, or else I can’t go to sleep”. And he said “well, coffee doesn’t let me sleep either. I can’t sleep thinking about that cup of coffee I want to drink. I drink it and I sleep fine”. Just remember, clever, and timing. Specially timing.Awkward silence. Gals want guys who know how to make conversation. And the best way to learn to talk with girls is to practice. Start conversations wirh girls, and with strangers (but be careful) when you’re sitting somewhere waiting for your turn, or on the bus, on the train, so on. If it doesn’t go well, you can say “I’m sorry. I’m trying to learn to make conversation”. Memorize that.A guy that talks too much. Because nobody likes that. It’s annoying. So again. It is a balance. Not be too silent, not talk too much.Don’t let her know you like her. Compliment her, talk with her, spend time with her, give her space (it’s a balance), but in a way that could be excused as friends, but is actually flirtatious. Whatever you do, don’t confirm nor deny that you’re friends. Same for whether or not you like her. As you spend more time together, you’ll become closer and closer until you two get together.. Fourth thought: With that second thought you could learn how to teach something quick, and in under five minutes. . Fifth thought: with that third thought, you could learn to make conversation, and that nobody likes someone who talks too much. . Sixth thought: you probably will forget everything if you try to learn everything in five minutes or less. So if that’s all the time you have, stop reading, and focus on the tips from third thought since they are the most helpful stuff in this answer. . Seventh thought: not to brag, but I think I’ve probably taught you way more than the other answers that were here by the time I started making this answer. . Eigth thought: I probably taught you something else with the sixth thought. . Ninth thought: actually, even if you read all of this instead of focusing in one thing, some if it might stay with you. . I had some other thoughts but I’ve spent too much time here anyway. So I’ll leave it there.

There is one 5-minute habit that I’ve incorporated into my day about two years ago. I practice it every morning. And what it’s done for me is quite impressive — it’s made me feel better about the day, more optimistic, and I’d say even happier. What is this small habit? I take a few moments early in the morning to sit and quietly think how grateful I am for what I have going on in my life right now. Practicing gratitude isn’t an isolated activity. It makes a shift in our mindset (the way we think about situations, things, people), and this in turn has a huge impact in the way we see our own life. What are specific benefits I’ve noticed from practicing gratitude? It trains my brain to think about positive things. These can be specific things that I’m doing, thinking about, or working on incrementally in small steps. They’re not things or behaviors others want of me, or things other people have, or achievements by anyone else. The biggest benefit? When I start the day thinking about the + and not the - , I’ve found that my brain stays longer focused on the good stuff. It’s as if the positive becomes a theme for the whole day, and it keeps my mood up.It helps me see my life as plentiful. Ever heard of the saying, You can see the glass as half-empty or half-full? Here’s how that saying pertains to real-life scenarios. Think of experiences and people, not just things. It helps you expand your understanding of the word have. And it works — I’ve found that there are always new items I want to add to this list. For example, this morning I thought about how grateful I am for spending a fun day with family over the holidays, as well as for several beautifully written comments on my Quora answers.It improves the attitude I have towards other people. As you know from your own life experiences, other people’s behaviors and reactions are difficult to predict, and often impossible to anticipate. In some cases, there are people who we enjoy spending time with, and there are others who will provoke, irritate, and upset us. With a gratitude mindset, I started treating every interaction (both at work and in my personal and social life) as a learning experience. I also try to find one small thing in each conversation that can be beneficial to me in some way. For example, if I talk to a person with a negative and critical mindset, it motivates me to brainstorm new ways to practice optimism. Conversely, enjoying a discussion with a curious and intelligent friend motivates me to optimize ways to boost my imagination, shape ideas for personal projects, or incorporate shortcuts to work smarter.How can you start building this simple habit into your day? It’s easier than you think. If you read these 3 tips, you’ll see what I mean. Tip #1. Practice early. When you start your day expressing gratitude, you will feel the effects throughout the day. Take a few minutes when you wake up and before you start getting ready for work or school. Give yourself some quiet time to focus on what you want to say. You might want to close your eyes while you think about it, or maybe you’ll want to write your thoughts down in a journal and then say them out loud. Pick whatever feels more natural to you. Tip #2. Start small. Practicing gratitude isn’t anything abstract or philosophical—it’s about real people, things, experiences, and events. As you sit quietly, focus on 3 things you are grateful for today. It can be the simplest of things: having a warm bed to sleep in, a roof over your head, a sunny sky, a close friend you trust, a pet that you like spending time with when you come home, etc. Or, it can be an object you find beautiful and that you have in your home, but that you don’t always pay attention to — a plant on your windowsill or a painting on your bedroom wall. Finally, it can be an enjoyable moment you shared the day before with a close friend or partner — think about how the time spent with them made you feel. Tip #3. Be specific. If it’s that one person — friend, partner, or confidante — that you’re grateful for having in your life, be sure to emphasize which of their qualities you are grateful for (they’re warm, smart, funny, creative, honest, etc.). If you really like having your own room or apartment, point out why this is important to you (you have personal freedom to enjoy quiet time in the evening to relax, and to sleep undisturbed when you need to). And if it’s being part of a group (your running mates with whom you hike on weekends or friends who share your love of music or film), reflect on how being around them makes you feel, and recall a recent event you all attended together and what made it fun and enjoyable.
